STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
June 28, 2023
Cathey Prudhomme
Eagle Village Ashmun-Sherk
17220 W Village Rd.
Hersey, MI, 49639-9756
Re: License #: CI670290156
Investigation #: 2023C0000451
Dear Ms. Prudhomme,
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• Repeat violations
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS/Division of Child Welfare Licensing
701 South Elmwood Suite 11
Traverse City, MI 49684
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

Hersey, MI 49639-9756
License Status: Regular
License Expiration Date: 05/18/2024
Capacity: 10

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(d) Storage of medications.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth overdosed on 5/8/23 on a bottle of ibuprofen and was taken
from the facility to the hospital. On 5/9/23, the medication cart was
left out and youth accessed it once more, taking more Ibuprofen,
leading to another hospitalization due to another overdose. Both
overdoses were self-harm related.
2

Investigation Interviews:
Complainant provided medical documents to DHHS Worker
after receiving Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services Request for Medical Information. Complaint had no
further information to provide.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 10
and via Teams on May 31, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Youth A reported Staff 1 allowed her to go back in the
back office, where the medication cart is located, by herself to get
Tide Pods and later the same night to return the bag of Tide Pods.
Youth A reported Staff 1 was the only staff on shift at that time due
to it being third shift. Youth A described Staff 1 talking with
another youth when Youth A went through the staff office and into
the back room. Youth A stated it was during this time she took
one bottle of Ibuprofen from the unlocked medication cart. Youth
A stated the medication cart is supposed to be locked but she
believed Staff 1 unlocked the medication cart because someone
asked for Tylenol and then left the medication cart unlocked.
Youth A stated the staff office door was open and the door to
where the medication cart and Tide Pods are kept was unlocked.
Youth A stated she hid the Ibuprofen bottle downstairs in the
laundry room’s trash can. Youth A reported the door into the
laundry room was unlocked and no one was with her when she
went to do laundry and hide the bottle. Youth A denied any staff
giving her Tide Pods. Youth A stated she waited until Staff 3 and
Staff 5 left the house to take approximately nine Ibuprofen pills.
Youth A stated it, “really was just Staff 1’s fault.”
Youth A reported she got the bottle of Ibuprofen from the laundry
room the next day (05/9/23), brought the bottle to her bedroom,
and took 13 Ibuprofen pills Youth A first took nine Ibuprofen pills
around 11:00pm on 5/7/23 and took 13 pills the afternoon of
5/9/23. Youth A denied any staff member following her around
that day and stated no one saw her take the pills. Youth A stated
she told a staff member, she could not recall who, she took more
pills.
Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
May 10 and via Teams on May 31, 2023, in collaboration with
DHHS Worker. Supervisor 1 reported Youth A told her she went
in the back room and got Tide Pods with Staff 1, saw the
medication cart was unlocked and grabbed the bottle of Ibuprofen.
Supervisor 1 stated Youth A told her she went downstairs into the
laundry room and hid the bottle in the trash can. Supervisor 1
3

reported Staff 1 told her the medication cart was unlocked
because she had been organizing the cart. Supervisor 1 stated
the expectation is the medication cart is never unlocked unless it
is during medication pass. Supervisor 1 reported occasionally the
staff office door is unlocked but the door to where the medication
cart is located is always locked. Supervisor 1 denied ever finding
the medication cart unlocked, seeing the medication keys sitting
on top of the medication cart or staff bringing it to her attention
these things were happening. Supervisor 1 reported staff are to
give youth Tide Pods to do laundry, not have a youth get the Tide
Pods themselves. Supervisor 1 reported later on Monday
(05/08/2023), she assisted Youth A with laundry and never saw
Youth A with an Ibuprofen bottle. Supervisor 1 stated she
searched Youth A’s bedroom on Monday (05/08/23) but the room
had already been cleared.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on May
10, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Therapist denied
Youth A having a history of taking pills or self-harming. Therapist
described Youth A as a “fighter,” being physically assaultive to
staff and law enforcement. Therapist stated Youth A taking pills is
completely new behavior for Youth A. Therapist reported she was
the one to find the Ibuprofen bottle in Youth A’s bedroom.
Therapist stated when she was notified Youth A took more pills on
Tuesday (05/9/2023) Therapist searched Youth A’s bedroom and
found one bottle of Ibuprofen between the wood bed frame and
mattress. Therapist stated initially Youth A refused to go to the
emergency room but ended up going with Supervisor 1. Therapist
was notified after the first incident of Youth A taking the Ibuprofen.
Therapist assessed Youth A and put a safety plan in place when
Youth A returned from the hospital. After the second time Youth A
took the Ibuprofen, Therapist met with Youth A after returning from
the hospital and the safety plan was updated.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 10,
2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Youth B denied ever
seeing any youth go into the staff office or back office by
themselves. Youth B stated, “staff would lose their job if they
allowed that.” Youth B reported occasionally seeing youth go into
the staff office, but a staff member is always with them. Youth B
reported the medication is stored in the back “somewhere.”
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 11
and via Teams on June 5, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Staff 1 described coming onto shift at 9pm on Monday
(5/8/2023) and having Staff 3 open the door to the room where the
4

medication cart is located because Staff 1 did not have an key.
Staff 1 reported when she started her shift the staff office door
was unlocked, the medication cart was unlocked but the door
leading to the room where the medication cart is located was
locked. Staff 1 stated she went to the medication cart, she
counted the medication, signed the book, locked the medication
cart, and set the medication cart keys on top of the medication
cart. Staff 1 stated she did not close the door on her way out
because Staff 3 was going to go back to the room. Staff 1
reported she went to check on the youth and talked with Youth B.
Staff 1 stated during this time she had not yet seen Youth A and
did not realize Youth A was not in her bedroom. Staff 1 reported
she talked with Staff 3 and Staff 5 prior to them leaving shift. Staff
1 stated Staff 5 gave Staff 1 the key before leaving shift. Staff 1
denied going back to the staff office or the office where the
medications are located until after Youth A took the pills. Staff 1
reported Youth A came upstairs with a bag of Tide Pods and
asked to put them away in the back office, where the medication
cart is located. Staff 1 stated she allowed Youth A to put the Tide
Pods away by herself because Staff 1 “trusted” Youth A. Staff 1
reported Youth A promptly put the bag of Tide Pods away and
came out from the offices with nothing in her hands. Staff 1
described Youth A wearing a Hello Kitty onesie with pockets.
Staff 1 reported Youth A stayed in her bedroom until
approximately 11pm when Youth A came out for a drink of water.
Staff 1 stated Youth A pulled red circular pills out of her pocket
and asked Staff 1, “Is this enough to kill me?” Staff 1 reported
Youth A put the pills in her mouth and chugged the water. Staff 1
stated she put her hand up to Youth A’s cheeks and squeezed to
have Youth A spit out the pills. Staff 1 reported Youth A spit out
two pills and went to get more water. Staff 1 described calling
Staff 4 for assistance. Staff 1 reported Staff 4 arrived and sat with
Youth A in the living area. Staff 1 denied finding the Ibuprofen
bottle or seeing Staff 4 find the bottle and returning it to the
medication cart. Staff 1 stated she took one of the pills Youth A
spit out to the medication cart to compare medication. Staff 1
reported she had to unlock the staff door to get to the door that led
to the medication cart. Staff 1 stated this was the first time she
noticed the medication cart was unlocked, as she had locked the
medication cart after counting the medication and starting her
shift. Staff 1 stated the lead staff, either Staff 3 or Staff 5, should
have locked the medication cart prior to leaving their shift.
Staff 1 stated the door leading to where the medication cart is
located is usually locked. Staff 1 reported there is at least one
5

time she recalled the staff door, the door to the medication cart
and the medication cart all being unlocked. Staff 1 reported she is
unsure why the keys to the medication cart are left on top of the
cart. Staff 1 stated she was trained that way although policy does
not say to leave the keys on top of the medication cart. Staff 1
stated staff normally leave the medication keys on top of the
medication cart. Staff 1 stated sometimes youth are allowed back
in the staff office with or without supervision. Staff 1 reported staff
are trained to not let youth back in the office, but it is sometimes
overlooked.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on May 11 and May 31,
2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 2 described
getting called late Sunday night (5/7/23) to take Youth A to the
emergency room because Youth A had taken some Ibuprofen.
Staff 2 reported she took Youth A to the emergency room and
returned early Monday morning. Staff 2 stated when returning
with Youth A, Youth A’s bedroom had not been cleared so she sat
in the living room with Youth A while Youth A’s bedroom was
cleared. Staff 2 stated Youth A was placed on a safety plan and
was to have her room cleared. Staff 2 reported searching Youth
A's bedroom but not searching anywhere else. Staff 2 reported
she primarily works at a different house on campus. Staff 2 stated
at the Ashmun and Sherk houses the medication keys are left on
top of the medication cart. Staff 2 reported at the house she
works at the medication cart keys are hid.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 11
and via Teams June 1, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Staff 3 stated Youth A asked for 17 Tide Pods on
Sunday night to do laundry. Staff 3 reported she told Youth A no
and handed Youth A four Tide Pods. Staff 3 denied allowing
Youth A into the staff office or office where the medication cart is
located to get the Tide Pods or giving Youth A the bag of Tide
Pods. Staff 3 denied seeing Youth A go into the staff office or
office where the medication cart is kept. Staff 3 stated she gave
Youth A four Tide Pods at approximately 8:50pm, prior to Staff 1
arriving on shift. Staff 3 reported she did not unlock the laundry
room door for Youth A to do laundry and does not recall Youth A
coming up from downstairs with anything in her hands. Staff 3
reported when Staff 1 arrived on shift, Staff 1 asked her to unlock
the door where the medication cart is located. Staff 3 stated Staff
1 signed the logbook and started her shift. Staff 3 reported Staff 5
had the medication cart keys on her. Staff 3 stated all the youth
were in their rooms, including Youth A, when Staff 3 and Staff 5
left for the evening. Staff 3 reported she was unaware if the
6

medication cart was locked when she left for the evening as she
was not responsible for medication that day. Staff 3 reported the
doors lock when they are shut. Staff 3 denied ever seeing the
medication cart keys left on top of the medication cart. Staff 3
stated the door to where the medication cart is located is always
locked and the medication cart is always locked. Staff 3 reported
occasionally the staff office door is left open. Staff 3 reported the
medication cart keys are kept on a staff member or hid in the room
where the medication cart is located.
Staff 3 stated Youth A told her on Tuesday (5/9/23) at
approximately 2:50-3pm that she had taken more pills. Staff 3
reported Youth A was in her bedroom when she told Staff 3. Staff
3 denied seeing Youth A take the pills and that Youth A was on
five-minute checks. Staff 3 stated Supervisor 1 was notified, and
Therapist came to the house. Staff 3 reported Therapist found
one Ibuprofen bottle in Youth A’s bed and Youth A was
transported to the emergency room.
Staff 4 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 24
and via telephone on May 31, 2023, in collaboration with
DHHS Worker. Staff 4 reported when he arrived to assist with
Youth A, he took one empty Ibuprofen bottle from Youth A and put
it back in the medication cart. On Mary 24, 2023, Staff 4 stated he
could not recall if the door to the staff office was open or closed.
Staff 4 reported the door to where the medication cart is located
was locked and the medication cart was locked. On May 31,
2023, Staff 4 stated he had to unlock the staff door to get back
into the office where the medication cart is located. Staff 4
described the medication cart and the door leading to where the
medication cart is located is to be always locked. Staff 4 stated,
“mostly everyone abides by regulation.” Staff 4 reported it is “rare”
but sometimes he has seen the medication keys sitting on top of
the medication cart and/or the medication cart unlocked.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 24
and via Teams on May 31, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Staff 5 reported Youth A asked Staff 3 for Tide Pods to
do laundry. Staff 5 stated she was down the hallway when Youth
A walked pass her with her laundry basket heading downstairs to
do laundry. Staff 5 reported she did not see Youth A go into the
back office to get the Tide Pods or see Youth A carrying any Tide
Pods. Staff 5 stated Staff 1 was not at the facility during this time.
Staff 5 reported Staff 1 arrived at the facility, had forgotten her key
so Staff 5 unlocked the staff office for Staff 1. Staff 5 reported
Youth A had come back upstairs, or Staff 3 and Staff 5 would not
7

have left for the evening. Staff 5 stated Staff 3 locked the staff
office door prior to leaving shift. Staff 5 reported the medication
cart was locked prior to leaving shift, Staff 5 believes she was the
one to lock the medication cart. Staff 5 reported youth are not
allowed in the back office, but staff have allowed youth in the past
but always with eyes on, never alone. Staff 5 stated she recalled
times when the door to where the medication cart is located being
unlocked and seeing the medication keys on top of the medication
cart. Staff 5 reported the medication keys are supposed to be on
staff or hid in the office where the medication cart is located.
Supervisor 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
May 24, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Supervisor
2 stated she recalled training Staff 1 but does not recall what
policies she specially trained. Supervisor 2 reported Staff 1 was
her partner in academy training. Supervisor 2 stated staff are
trained to keep the medication cart keys in their pocket or on the
metal packet on the side of the medication cart, never to leave the
medication keys on top of the medication cart. Supervisor 2
reported the door leading to the medication cart is always to be
locked. Supervisor 2 stated she has seen the staff door unlocked,
medication keys on top of the medication cart or the medication
cart unlocked and has addressed it with staff right away.
Video Reviewed:
Video of incidents from 5/7/23 and 5/9/23 were not available.
Video footage of May 10, 2023, at 9:53pm shows Staff 1 enter the
room where the medication cart is located and the medication cart
keys laying on top of the cart. Video shows Staff 1 unlock the
medication cart with the keys, lock the medication cart and place
the keys back on top of the medication cart prior to leaving the
room.
Documents Reviewed:
• Incident reports for Youth A dated 05/07/2023 starting at
11:03pm when Youth A first took the pills through
05/09/2023 at 3:57pm. Incident report completed by Staff 1
describes Staff 3 bringing Youth A to the back office and
giving Youth A four Tide pods, this is different then what
Staff 1 reported in the interview. The incident reports
describe multiple occasions of Youth A showing physical
and verbal aggression toward Staff 1.
• Residential Services Standard Operating Procedures,
Residential Storage of Medication: Policy states, “All
medication shall be stored in the locked medication cart.
8

This locked cart will be placed in a location within each
residence that is an area restricted to residents and that
requires entrance through one locked door. This includes
all over the counter medications and PRN medications.”
• Residential Services Standard Operating Procedures,
Standards for Drug Administration: Policy states, “Keys to
the medication carts are never to be left on top of the cart.”
• Spectrum Health Reed City Hospital Emergency Room
report for Youth A dated 5/8/2023: Describes Youth A
ingesting nine 200mg tablets of Ibuprofen, which is less than
the 24-hour maximal dose. Youth A was discharged in
stable condition.
• Spectrum Health Reed City Hospital Emergency Room
report for Youth A dated 5/9/2023: Report indicates Youth A
had toxic ingestion yesterday (5/8/23) by taking 9 tablets,
with by weight were under the toxic level, however Youth A
reported taking 13 200mg tablets of Ibuprofen today from the
same bottle she had yesterday. With the increased dosage
amount, Youth A obtained salicylate and acetaminophen
levels. Youth A was evaluated by CMH, it was not believed
this was a suicide attempt. Youth A admitted to CMH she
did this to get out of the house. Doctor’s note states he gave
caregiver (Supervisor 1) the “option” of having the
psychiatrist see the patient on telehealth in the morning
(5/10/23).
• Progress note from Eagle Village Psychiatrist dated
5/11/2023: Youth A refused to meet with psychiatrist. Youth
A left school without permission and was refusing to follow
staff’s direction. Youth A is not on any medication at this
time.
• Progress note from Eagle Village Psychiatrist dated
4/27/2023: Youth A making good progress, progressing well
in therapy and is not on any medication.
• Safety Plan for Youth A dated 5/7/23 and 5/9/23: Outlines
what is allowed in Youth A’s bedroom, supervision of Youth
A and variable 5-minute checks.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as Youth A was
unsupervised and enter the room where medication is stored.
Multiple staff interviewed reported leaving or seeing medication
cart keys left on top of the medication cart. Multiple staff
interviewed reported seeing the medication cart unlocked, the
door leading to where the medication cart is located unlocked, and
the staff office door open or unlocked at various times.
9

It is unclear as to when Youth A got the medication from the
medication cart. Staff 1 admitted to allowing Youth A access to
the medication room unsupervised to return the Tide pod bag after
Youth A returned upstairs. Youth A reported she took the bottle of
Ibuprofen at this time but also told Supervisor 1 she hid the bottle
of Ibuprofen in the trash can in the basement laundry room.
According to interviews Youth A did not return to the laundry room
that night but the first incident of taking pills occurred soon after
Youth A put the Tide pods away in the medication room.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
Section The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency’s program statement and to provide for
the continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Youth's safety plan was not followed. Staff member assigned to
five-minute checks fell asleep and five-minute log sheets showed
the youth was not being monitored every five minutes.
Investigation Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 11
and via Teams on June 5, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Staff 1 reported Staff 2, who was working third shift with
Staff 1, fell asleep when assigned to complete five-minute checks
on Youth A. (do we have date?) Staff 1 stated Staff 2 falls asleep
quite often. Staff 1 reported Staff 2 had to sit outside of Youth A’s
bedroom door and complete five-minute checks because Youth A
was on a safety plan. Staff 1 stated the five-minute log sheets
have not been filled out correctly with a few hours blank on the
sheet. Staff 1 reported staff members are violating Youth A’s
safety plan by allowing Youth A to have more than one blanket,
stuffed animal, and clothes in the bedroom. Staff 1 stated Youth A
should only have one blanket and one pillow in the bedroom.
Staff 1 stated she has had to remind staff members Youth A must
have eyes on at all times. Staff 1 denied voicing her concerns to
anyone at the facility until now.
Staff 2 was interviewed via telephone on May 11 and May 31,
2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Staff 2 reported she
was told Youth A was placed on a safety plan including five-
minute checks. Staff 2 described sitting outside of Youth A’s
bedroom on Monday (5/8/23) from 1 – 6am and Wednesday into
Thursday (5/10/23 into 5/11/23) from 12-6am. Staff 2 reported
10

she documented the five-minute interval checks on the log sheet.
Staff 2 denied sleeping while on shift. Staff 2 stated Youth A
asked for her teddy bear, but Staff 2 told her no because it was
not listed on her safety plan as an item she could have. Staff 2
reported Youth A was only allowed a pillow and blanket in her
room according to the safety plan. Staff 2 stated on Thursday
(5/11/23) Youth A had a few dirty clothes under her window in her
bedroom, a blue blanket and one stuffed animal.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 11
and via Teams June 1, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Staff 3 stated Youth A’s safety plan only allowed for a
pillow and blanket in Youth A’s bedroom. Staff 3 reported seeing
a sheet, stuffed animal, face mask, pillow, and blanket in Youth
A’s bedroom.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 24
and via Teams on May 31, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Staff 5 reported Youth A was on a safety plan where she
could not have anything in her room except for a blanket, pillow
and maybe a stuffed animal. Staff 5 could not recall if the stuffed
animal was allowed in Youth A’s bedroom as part of the safety
plan or not.
Video Reviewed:
Video from 5/11/2023 shows Staff 2, who is the assigned staff at
the time to complete five-minute checks on Youth A, sleeping from
1:53am until 2:06am. Staff 2 appears to wake up as Staff 1 is
walking down the bedroom hallway.
Tour Observation:
A tour of Youth A’s bedroom occurred on May 11, 2023. There
was one pillow, and two blankets found in Youth A’s bedroom, one
more blanket than the safety plan and policy allow.
Documents Reviewed:
• Residential Services Standard Operating Procedures,
Supervision of Residents, Close Observation: Policy states,
all items will be removed from the youth’s room, except for
a pillow (pillowcase needs to be removed) and comforter.
• Safety Plan for Youth A dated 5/7/23 and 5/9/23: Plan (i)
outlines all items be removed from Youth A’s room except
for a pillow (pillowcase needs to be removed), and
comforter; viii states - Once the youth is asleep, staff does
not need to sit directly outside their door, however; staff
must continue variable checks within 5 minutes from the
11

last check, this will be documented on the 5 Minute Log.
Example: If staff were sitting outside the youth’s door from
11pm-3am, they only need to write down “sitting outside
door from 11pm-3am” in the 5-minute log. They do not
have to write that every 5 minutes. Once 5-minute checks
resume, then staff document each 5 minute check on the
log.
• Supervision Logs for Youth A from May 8 – 11, 2023. Staff
did not document each five-minute check on the log sheet if
Youth A woke up. There were chunks of time describing
Youth A’s behaviors but no documentation confirming five-
minute checks were being completed.
• During the time Staff 2 was observed to be sleeping on
video, there were no checks documented during that time.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as different staff members
described seeing a stuffed animal, one additional blanket, face
mask, sheet and clothes in Youth A’s bedroom. The safety plan
did not allow for these additional items to be in Youth A’s
bedroom. Video shows Staff 2, who was assigned to observe
Youth A, sleeping from 1:53am until 2:06am. Documentation of
five-minute checks documented the checks being longer than five-
minutes. Reviewing the log sheets, it is unclear if five-minute
checks were completed as the times listed are grouped together
and not every five minutes.
Conclusion Violation Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program statement.
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff lacked professional boundaries when interacting with a
youth. Staff 5 gave Youth A a backrub and gave her a letter.
Investigation Supervisor 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
May 10 and via Teams on May 31, 2023, in collaboration with
DHHS Worker. Supervisor 1 reported she read the letter Staff 5
wrote to Youth A and gave Staff 5 permission to give Youth A the
letter. Supervisor 1 reported Staff 5 has a good rapport with
Youth A and the letter was meant to be encouraging. Supervisor
1 denied having any concerns with Staff 5’s relationship with
Youth A.
12

Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on May
10, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS Worker. Therapist was
unaware of the letter Staff 5 wrote to Youth A. Therapist reported
Youth A identifies Staff 5 along with a few other staff members as
sources of support. Therapist denied having any concerns with
Staff 5’s relationship with Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 11
and via Teams June 1, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Staff 3 denied having concerns with any staff members’
boundaries toward Youth A. Staff 3 stated she was not aware if
there was a policy stating staff members cannot write letters to
youth.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the facility on May 24
and via Teams on May 31, 2023, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker. Staff 5 described having a good relationship with Youth
A. Staff 5 stated Therapist, Supervisor 1 and herself were
probably the only ones Youth A trusts. Staff 5 describing writing
the letter to Youth A as a way to connect with her, encourage her
and remind her of what she has going for her once she leaves the
facility. Staff 5 reported Supervisor 1 read the letter and approved
Staff 5 giving the letter to Youth A. Staff 5 stated she saw the
letter as a way to get through to Youth A. Staff 5 stated she gave
Youth A a backrub because Youth A’s shoulder was hurting. Staff
5 reported there are physical touch boundaries and that she
“probably should not have done that.” Staff 5 stated she thought
she was on camera the entire time and did not realize her hands
went out of camera view.
Video Reviewed:
While reviewing video from May 10 and 11, 2023 the screen had
four sections of separate video from different times playing. On
the screen, one of the videos was Staff 5 giving Youth A a
backrub in the hallway outside of Youth A’s bedroom. After a
short period of time Youth A slides into her bedroom out of
camera view, and Staff 5 moves closer to the entrance of the
bedroom. Staff 5 raises her hands, and her hands go out of
camera view as they are inside Youth A’s bedroom.
Tour Observation:
A tour of Youth A’s bedroom occurred on May 11, 2023. A three-
page letter from Staff 5 to Youth A was found in Youth A’s bed.
Documents Reviewed:
13

• Letter from Staff 5 to Youth A: The letter talks about how
Staff 5 feels Youth A and her are similar, for Youth A to be
proud of her growth at the facility, to focus on how things
will be once she is discharged and to be open to
relationships and people.
• Residential Services Standard Operating Procedures, Staff
Code of Conduct: • Discussing personal business with
residents is discouraged, unless it is directly related to the
therapeutic benefit and growth of the resident. Self-
disclosure should be brief and focus should remain on the
resident. If staff have any questions about whether or not
such information is appropriate for the youth they should
withhold such information until such time that they can
solicit feedback from the treatment team, Residential Team
Supervisor, or Family Therapist. Supervisor 1 gave
permission to Staff 5 to give Youth A the letter. The only
form of physical contact addressed in policy states, “Staff
are permitted to give 3 second hugs; side by side. No full
body hugs. Developing and role modeling relationships
must occur within the context of professionalism so as to
avoid compromises to the staff and residents. At all times,
staff shall treat residents and coworkers with respect and
dignity in words and actions.”
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance for Staff 5 not following the
Staff Code of Conduct policy. Staff 5 was observed giving Youth
A a backrub. As Youth A enters her bedroom and is no longer
observed on camera, Staff 5 slides toward the bedroom and Staff
5’s hands go out of view of the camera.
Conclusion REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4112 Criminal history check, subject to
Section requirements; staff qualifications.
Description (4) A person with ongoing duties shall have both of the following:
(a) Ability to perform duties of the position assigned.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation Staff member lacks the ability to perform job duties.
Investigation During a telephone call on June 21, 2023, MDHHS worker
reported there was a preponderance of evidence and Staff 1 will
have a confirmed case.
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as Staff 1 has a confirmed
case.
14

Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statues and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
